KEY RESPONSIBILITIES

RESPONSIBILITY OFFICER • Preparing the Passage Plan. Navigation Officer • Reviewing & Approval of Passage plan. Master • Understanding, Acknowledgement & Signing of Passage plan. • Raising any concern/ doubt related to the plan with the master/ navigation officer. All OOBW • Execution & Monitoring of the Passage Plan. OOBW & Master • In consultation with Master, ensuring following are sufficient for the passage: • Bunkers, fresh water, lubes, etc. • Spare parts, tools, supplies etc. Chief Engineer 2.
REQUIREMENTS FOR PASSAGE PLAN

REQUIREMENT PASSAGE PLAN MUST Compliance • Comply with: • Applicable international, national, and regional regulations, • Company procedures and guidelines, • Prudent seamanship practices. Principles of passage planning • Follow below principles: • Appraisal • Planning • Execution • Monitoring • Debriefing Berth to Berth • Cover passage from berth to berth. • This includes: • Undocking and departure. • Passage enroute. • Approach and anchoring/ mooring at destination Readiness of Plan • Be ready & approved prior departure. !! If prior departure, the port of destination is not known, or voyage orders are received with insufficient time remaining to complete full plan, have the plan ready for: • First 48 hours of passage, or • Up to a safe position to drift awaiting voyage orders, whichever is least. Flexibility • Be flexible to accommodate any amendments due to changing conditions. • Record all amendments to the passage plan. Economy Vs Safety • Do not make savings in time, distance, and other associated “economies” at the expense of safety Risk Assessment • Include the control measures identified because of voyage specific Risk Assessment. 3.

Responsibility : Master Review the voyage orders and pass on relevant information to: OFFICER FOR PRELIMINARY ASSESSMENT OF Navigation Officer • Navigational passage. text: Preliminary Assessment of Passage

Responsibility : Master & Navigation Officer Conduct a preliminary assessment, to verify if vessel can: Safely call both load & discharge ports, & Safely transit areas with any limiting conditions. Assess factors including (but not limited to) following: UKC/ Drafts: • Vessel will be able to comply with UKC or Allowable Drafts at: • Load & discharge ports. • Any limiting transit areas e.g., Panama Canal transit, load line zones etc. Laycan: • Vessel will be able to comply with the Laycan requirements depending upon: • Vessel’s current position. • Expected speed. Vessel’s design or construction: • In case of any specific design/ construction requirements for the proposed region/ ports, vessel will be able to comply. • E.g., ports in Ice regions, where ice class is required. Insurance limitations: • Vessel will not breach any: • Institute warranty limits or • Other limitations imposed by the insurers. Cargo Restrictions: • Vessel will be able to maintain any special requirements for the proposed cargo while transiting. !! In case of any concerns or doubts, consult office & then inform the charterers accordingly. 4.2

text: To identify & gather all information required to plan the passage. It essentially involves following: • Use the form F088 Passage Plan 4.2.2
Checking Availability of Charts & Publications

Responsibility : Navigation Officer Charts/ ENCs As a part of Risk assessment (RA) in Sec 2 : Check ENC coverage using an updated digital chart catalogue supplied by approved chart supplier. Follow below: • Company vessels use NAVTOR Pay as you sail for ordering ENCs. See Doc 5.21.00 for more details • Check the “readme.txt” files of each weekly database to identify any amendment to the ENCs in the area of sailing. e.g., New ENCs, New editions and/or withdrawals of ENCs Publications Ensure nautical & other recommended publications affecting the passage are available on board. • List of publications is available in NAVTOR. • For list of publications required for the current passage, see Form F088 Passage Planning Obtain additional publications or local charts, if required due to local requirements of coastal states. • Always obtain information from local publications, agents, etc. 4.2.3

metadata.breadcrumb: 5.06 Passage Planning > Checking Availability of Charts & Publications

text: Updating Charts/ Publications & Other Information Sources

Responsibility : Navigation Officer Process Comply with below: ENCs & Publications corrections: • Ensure all Charts / ENCs and publications are corrected up to date. T&P Corrections & AIO: • Apply T&P Corrections to the voyage ENCs via AIO. !! Unless automated, manually insert T&P data into the ECDIS using 'Manual Update & Mariner's Notes'. • Consider T&Ps within 100 NM on either side of route as affecting the voyage. EPNMs: • Update EPNMs on the voyage ENCs. Navigational Warnings: • Plot NAVTEX, INM-C (SafetyNet – EGC) and NTM warnings, that affect the voyage, on the ENCs using manual update function. • Set these as alarm features if they affect safety. • Plot the warnings which are affecting voyage in arrange of 20nm or are within the 3 hours ahead of the ship’s planed route. • This is to avoid adding unnecessary information on the ECDIS display. Supplementary Safety Related Information: • Review ANM Weekly Notice section VIII for ‘Updates to Admiralty digital products & services’ for any relevant information that can impact the voyage. • For further details on above & the updating process, see Doc 5.21.00 Checking & Assurance Comply with below: Spot Checks: • Check correct application of ENC updates by making spot checks of ENCs at the end of appraisal. ECDIS internal log: • Inspect ECDIS internal log to: • Identify any updates which may have failed, or • Other abnormal conditions experienced by ECDIS, during update process. Installation Failure: • When updates for ENCs relevant to voyage, fail to install: • Investigate thoroughly. • Take remedial actions, such as: - Applying manual updates to clarify update content. - Consulting chart supplier or ECDIS manufacturer. Paper Charts: • If using paper charts as part of voyage plan, note the possibility of their differing update cycles than ENCs. Recordkeeping Maintain following records in NP 133C or equivalent electronic record: All ENC holdings. All ENCs installed on each ECDIS All updates applied to each ECDIS Terminal. All Navigational warnings and NMs received on board & corresponding actions taken. • INM-C EGC warnings shall be kept on file until they are deleted or canceled by the provider, or based on the last 'in-force' message for the area. • NAVTEX warnings are kept for the last voyage only, as they are regularly transmitted and will be received again when the vessel enters the area. 4.2.4

text: Collecting information from all sources

Responsibility : Navigation Officer Collect following information: VESSEL RELATED INFORMATION Manoeuvring Characteristics: • Refer Manoeuvring Booklet, Manoeuvring Poster Drafts & Trim: • Vessel’s estimated drafts for different stages of passage. • Consider Trim optimization as per SEEMP. Cargo: • Any specific Cargo related considerations. Equipment: • Condition of Navigation related equipment & machinery. !! If any Equipment / Machinery is not performing fully, additional controls would be required in planning stage e.g., increase in clearance distance/ UKC etc. PASSAGE RELATED INFORMATION Navigational Guidance/ aids, Reporting Requirements: • Refer Charts / ENCs and nautical publications like: • Sailing directions, Ocean passages for the world, Routeing charts, • Port information guides, • ADP, eNP. • Specific Area guides e.g., Malacca & Singapore Straits transit. !! Do not use outdated ENCs/ Publications. CATZOC data: • Check the quality of ENC data to be used for navigation. • Check the “readme.txt” files accompanying each weekly database for any reported depth inaccuracies in the area of sailing. • For more information on CATZOC, see Doc 5.07.00 Sec 3.6 and NP 231 Sec 5 • If possible, confirm port local depth data from authorities (Pilots/ Port Authorities). Tide: • Calculate height of tide using Tide Tables & Atlases. IMO Routeing: • Check & follow all mandatory (IMO) & voluntary Ship Routeing Systems if along the planned tract. • If special circumstances do not allow, take approval from office. Load Line zone: • Check and consider any restrictions. Weather Routeing: • Consult weather routeing publications or software. • Plot any restrictions, on ENC. • It is up to master’s discretion to use weather routing services. • For details, see Doc 5.15.00 , sec 2.2 Environmental Sensitive Areas: • Consider cautions when transiting Environmental Sensitive Areas. Security restrictions: • Seek advice of Ship Security Officer for any security related restrictions. • Refer to Maritime Security Charts, BMP publications, regional guidance (e.g., ReCAAP), company specific guidance (if available for an area). ADDITIONAL INFORMATION Charterer’s Instructions: • Review Navigation related instructions in charterer’s voyage orders. • Apply any necessary amendments to passage plan. • Mention details of such instructions in F088 Passage Planning Previous Passage Records: • Experience Feedback from previous voyages Debriefing Records. Specific instructions from master • Check any specific instructions by master, • e.g., if vessel must make a specific arrival time or specific safety margins. 4.2.5

Setting Up ECDIS for Planning

Responsibility : Navigation Officer Set up the ECDIS as follows before starting planning stage: SENC Layers/ ECDIS Display Settings: • Confirm ‘All’ layers and Object Groups are activated. • So, no information is lost while planning. • As the route planning progresses, consider removing layers such as data quality to improve clarity. Vessel Parameters: • Verify vessel parameters for the voyage. • E.g., Draft, Air Draft etc. SCAMIN: • Ensure SCAMIN is OFF • So that all details are available in all selected scales. Initial ECDIS Safety Settings: • Set initial ECDIS Safety Settings to start planning, as follows: • Safety Depth = Static Draft + Squat (At Maximum Speed) + UKC Policy (Deep Sea) • Safety contour = Safety depth • By default, the Safety Contour is set at 30 m. !! Use these only while outlining a basic route using smaller scale ENCs. Determine the safety settings for each leg of the voyage when fine tuning the route after considering additional factors like CATZOC, tides etc. • For details on: • ECDIS Safety Settings, see Doc 5.19.00 • UKC Policy see Doc 5.07.00 • For further details, refer to ECDIS specific Maker’s Manual on board. 4.3.3

metadata.breadcrumb: 5.06 Passage Planning > Setting Up ECDIS for Planning

text: Plotting the Route leg by leg & Vessel Settings

Responsibility : Navigation officer General Basis review of information collected during appraisal, start planning the route leg by leg. Follow below recommendation in the use of different scale band ENCs: STEP DESCRIPTION ENC BANDS • Start the planning process using smaller scale ENCs (Overview & General) outlining a basic route. Bands 1&2 • Move on to medium scale ENCs (Coastal ENCs) bringing in more detail to: • Refine the plan, & • Edit legs of the voyage, as proximity to safety contour decreases. Band 3 • Use approach, harbour and berthing ENC to prepare the pilotage detail. Bands 4,5 & 6 • For details on how to create route on ECDIS, check ECDIS specific Maker’s Manual. Vessel Settings & Other Considerations While Plotting Courses When plotting or fine tuning the route, consider following factors for each leg: RELATED TO ACTION FURTHER DETAILS Accuracy of ENCs • Account for the inaccuracies due to poorly surveyed areas by reviewing CATZOC data. !! When calculating Safety Depth & Safety Contour add corresponding Safety Margin to the UKC calculations. Doc 5.07.00 Draft & UKC Required • Ensure full compliance with UKC policy. Doc 5.08 Air Draft & OHC • Ensure full compliance with Overhead Clearance policy. Doc 5.09 No Go Areas • Basis the rough route, mark no go areas prior to plotting/ fine-tuning route for each leg on the largest scale ENC. Doc 5.19.00 Turn Radius & Wheel over points • Apply Correct turn data to waypoints. Doc 5.19.00 ENC Features & Date / Time • If seasonal features lie along the planned track, make note of them with their time constraints. Doc 5.19.00 Leg Characteristics • Plan details of each leg, including cross track distance (XTD) carefully. • Do Not copy from the previous legs. Doc 5.19.00 Tidal Correction • Account for Tidal Corrections. Doc 5.19.00 Mariner’s Notes • Add Mariner’s notes as required. Doc 5.19.00 Look Ahead & Alarms • Set Look ahead & Alarms. Doc 5.19.00 ECDIS Safety Parameters • Finalize ECDIS Safety settings. Doc 5.19.00 Crossing the Safety Contour • In a scenario where route needs to cross a Safety Contour, follow the Company recommended Method. • Method 2 as per NP232 Doc 5.19.00 Guard Zone • Set the guard zone or anti-grounding cone. Doc 5.19.00 4.3.4

text: Markings on ENCs

Responsibility : Navigation Officer Mark / check, following on ENCs during passage planning, considering the hazards of each leg of passage: INFORMATION • Parallel Index lines. • Position Fixing/ Verification - Methods & Frequency. • Prominent navigation & radar marks. • No Go Areas/ Limiting Danger lines. !! Avoid excessive marking of No-go areas. • Landfall targets & lights. • Clearing lines & bearings (Danger Bearings). • Transits, heading marks and leading lines. • Significant tides or currents. • Safe speed and necessary speed alterations. • Changes in Machinery Status. • Minimum UKC. • Points at which Echo Sounder should be activated/ checked. • Crossing & High-density traffic areas. • Safe distance off. • Anchor Clearance. • Contingency Plans/ Anchorage/ Port of Refuge - To be used in emergencies. • Abort Points • VTS and Reporting points etc. • Air draft when passing under bridges/ power lines/ cable cars etc. • Call Master points. • Bridge Status/ Manning Level • Any other user defined notifications as considered necessary. !! Do not overburden the ENC with irrelevant material. 4.3.5
Route Validation

General Responsibility : Navigation Officer After plotting, the route along with voyage details on the ENC, validate the route as follows: !! Manual Route Validation is very important because the auto validation considers the hazards within the defined XTL. Therefore, hazards to navigation near the plotted course are not identified. Order to Perform Route validation ROUTE REVALIDATION – Carry out after: • Any subsequent route changes, • ENCs automatic updates (Weekly NTMs are applied) • Software/hardware updates; • A new database is installed. • Navigational warnings (Navarea, NAVTEX, MSI) are plotted manually on the ENCs. 4.3.6

Position Fixing/ Verification Intervals & Methods • Position Fixing’ generally relates to the paper charts, however when it comes to ECDIS, the term used is ‘Position Verification’ as the position is automatically ‘fixed’ by GNSS and available continuously in real time. Position Verification Interval Responsibility : Navigation Officer Establish Frequency of position verification based on: Area: • Area vessel is navigating. Conditions: • Prevailing conditions. Distance off: • Distance off the nearest hazard. Chart Accuracy: • Position accuracy of chart type in use. i.e., CATZOC. Follow maximum time interval between verification as follows: AREA OPERATION IN FULL ECDIS MODE OTHER MODES (Paper charts, RNC etc.) Open Sea Passages • 4 hours • 1 hour Coastal Sea Passage • 60 minutes (or less at Master’s Discretion) • 20 minutes Restricted Waters and/or confined waters • 30 minutes • 6 minutes Pilotage • As per area of pilotage (e., f. or g.) above • While vessel at anchor, ECDIS is set at anchor watch and GNSS position should be double checked with LOPs at intervals not greater than 60 minutes Position Verification Methods • In principle always have at least 2 methods of Position Fixing. Since one method is always available in the form of GNSS, have at least one more Verification Method at all times. Set position Verification Method as follows: AREA ALWAYS AVAILABLE VERIFICATION METHODS Open Sea Passage GNSS/ GPS (On ECDIS) • Celestial Observations • Cross checking that both GPs data coincide. • Comparison of the Signal to Noise ratio (S/N) or Carrier to Noise ratio (C/N) of the GPS in use. • Dilution of Position (DOP) check of the GPS in use. • See user manual for details on S/N, C/N, DOP. • Use RIO alignment method to check with the coastline [if within range]. • Primary • Secondary Coastal Sea Passage • Within 20 NM of coast & • Inshore of 50 m contour GNSS/ GPS (On ECDIS) • Visual bearing and Radar distance. • Visual bearings from fixed objects based at least on two position lines however most accurate and reliable means are considered three position lines if visibility permits • Radar bearings and distances. • Compass bearings and Radar distances. • Cross bearing by gyro or magnetic compass. • Sextant horizontal and vertical angles observations. • Visual/ Radar Bearing & Chart Soundings. • Check soundings when making a landfall & when navigating in restricted or shallow waters. • Use RIO alignment method to check with the coastline [if within range]. !! Maximum acceptable deviation between primary and secondary fixing 0.1 nm (One cable) or less at Master’s discretion • Secondary • Primary Restricted / Confined Waters GNSS/ GPS (On ECDIS) • Same as above !! Maximum acceptable deviation between primary and secondary fixing 0.05 nm (Half cable) or less at Master’s discretion • Secondary • Primary 4.3.7
Information to Include in the Final Passage Plan

Responsibility : Navigation Officer As a minimum include following information in the final passage plan: • The information can be displayed on the ECDIS and/or covered in form F088 Passage Planning ENCs & Publications: • List of ENCs & Publications used. • Any backup RNCs or Paper Charts where ENC coverage is unsuitable. Doc 5.19.00 Courses & Distances: • Planned track / Courses & distance of each leg. Speed: • Planned speed for each leg of the passage / speed restrictions. Doc 5.11 ECDIS Safety Settings: • Safety contour add safety depth setting for each leg Doc 5.19.00 ECDIS Display settings: • Include each point where the display settings need to be changed. Doc 5.19.00 Other ECDIS settings: • Other key ECDIS settings including palette, features displayed, & Other options. Doc 5.19.00 Leg settings: • Example XTD, Look Ahead Zone. Doc 5.19.00 ETAs: • ETAs at critical points in the plan. Wheel over Position & Turn Radius: • For each alteration as applicable. Doc 5.19.00 Areas to Avoid: • Documented areas to be avoided including clearance within the ECDIS. Notes: • Notes covering any useful relevant local information, & regulatory restrictions Traffic: • Areas likely to have high traffic density. Pilotage: • Areas under international rules considered to be port, deep sea mandatory or voluntary pilotage waters. Doc 5.14.00 Position Fixing: • Methods and frequency of primary and backup position fixing. Sec 4.3. 6 Parallel Indexing & Visual cues: • Navigational marks, & • Radar ranges or parallel indices and other visual cues like leading lights. • To cross check/ monitor vessel’s position. Doc 5.11 Contingency Plans & Abort Point: • For emergencies including all contingency actions which would place the vessel in safe water, at port of refuge or at a safe anchorage. • Alternative or contingency routeing that may be required at short notice Environmentally Sensitive Areas: • Information and guidance for passages through environmentally sensitive areas. Doc 5.13 Security Related Information: • For each leg of the voyage, e.g.: • Changes to Security Level. • Changes to BWL due to security concerns. • Where to implement Hardening Measures. Charterers’ Instructions: • As applicable for the voyage. Currents, Tides: • Information regarding Currents, tides. Navigational Hazards: • Description of Navigational hazards. Reporting: • Reporting points and Channels to maintain VHF watch. Ship Reporting Systems: • Ship Reporting Systems (Mandatory & Voluntary) applicable to the voyage area. • E.g., INSPIRES, AMVER, SISTRAM etc. For details, see ALRS Vol 6. Doc 5.11 UKC/ OHC: • UKC & Overhead Clearance information. Doc 5.07.00 , 5.08 Machinery Space • Changes in machinery space status i.e., manned or unmanned. • Changes in machinery status i.e., standby or manoeuvring. • Changes to fuel &/or scrubber use. Local information • Specific guidance provided by local routing publications where applicable to the vessel and its route. Additional Personnel: • Positions where to call Master, additional deck officers, additional personnel. Doc 5.11 , 5.05.00 bb. Master’s Comments: • Any specific comments/ instructions by the Master regarding the passage. !! Expect the vessel to deviate from the planned passage to the extent necessary to safely comply with COLREGS.

text: Responsibility : Navigation Officer After preparing the passage plan (on ECDIS & form F088 ) submit to Master for approval. Responsibility : Master Prior approving the Passage Plan, verify: All ENCs and publications are corrected & updated to latest notice. • Use ‘ENC Status Report’ to verify if all ENCs for the planned route are up-to-date. UKC & OHC calculations are correct. Review the passage plan on ECDIS and supplementary information in form F088 . • Ensure all key aspects of planning as defined in above sections are adequately complied with. Responsibility : Navigation Officer Load and synchronize authorized voyage plan on all ECDIS terminals. Responsibility : All Bridge OOW Read and understand the passage plan. Share any concerns or experience with the navigation officer. Once satisfied, sign the passage plan form F088 . • Repeat Voyages: If on a regular passage, same basic plan may be used again, provided: • New Passage Plan Form ( F088 ) is completed • Fresh review & authorization process is followed as above. • When a Passage is planned, all courses, safety contours, waypoints and notes are saved in the system and stored in the Passage or routes subfolder for use again if the Passage is repeated 4.4

metadata.breadcrumb: 5.06 Passage Planning > Passage Plan Review & Approval

text: Pre-Voyage Meeting

Responsibility : Master Prior to sailing hold a meeting with all Bridge Team Members, to discuss: All aspects of the passage plan, Learnings from any previous visits. Record the meeting in Deck logbook. Responsibility : Bridge Team Members If in doubt regarding safe navigation for any part of the passage, raise the concern with Master. Responsibility : Master If an agreement cannot be reached, consult office for guidance. If operational constraints prevent above prior sailing, conduct same at first opportunity. • Recommendation: It would be beneficial to have the Chief Engineer or 2nd Engineer attend this meeting. If that is not practicable, brief them separately about requirements on: • Critical areas of the voyage. • Requirements of standby engines/ manoeuvering speed. • Likelihood of bad weather • Other constraints expected during the voyage where additional steering gear, electrical power etc.would be required. 4.4.2
Execution of the Passage Plan

General Responsibility : Master / OOW Consider following for execution of passage: ETAs for Tide: • ETAs at critical points for accurate assessment of tidal heights and flow. ETAs for Daylight: • ETAs at critical points where it is preferable to make a daylight passage. Traffic Conditions: • Traffic conditions at focal points Destination ETA: • ETA at destination particularly where there may be no advantage gained by early arrival Tidal Streams: • Tidal streams information obtained basis times of transit Vessel’s Equipment: • Reliability of the vessel’s equipment, especially navigation equipment. Weather: • Weather forecasts and any adverse effect on the plan. Nav Warnings: • Receipt of latest Nav Warnings affecting passage. Drafts: • Actual Drafts and UKC at every leg of passage. Related to ECDIS Consider following when conducting the Execution phase (not exhaustive): Activating Plan: • Activate the correct Navigation Plan on primary & backup ECDIS Terminals. !! Ensure SCAMIN is ON Screen Display: • Display the most relevant panel or screen display for execution. Safety Settings & Alarms: • Ensure appropriate configuration of Safety Settings & Alarms • Anti-Grounding Cone, Safety Depth, Safety Contour, Safety Parameters etc. Manual Updates • Ensure settings allow manual updates to be displayed on the ECDIS. Route: • Follow the Route and know the XTD in case of deviation. Information from Sensors: • Verify information from all sensors connected to ECDIS is available & correct. !! Give particular attention to GNSS, Gyro Compass & log. 4.5

metadata.breadcrumb: 5.06 Passage Planning > Execution of the Passage Plan

text: • This stage is about ensuring that the vessel follows the passage plan. It is the primary function of the OOBW. 4.5.1

Responsibility : OOBW Closely & continuously monitor compliance with the passage plan by: Position Verification Frequency: • Verifying position of the vessel as per established frequency in passage plan. Position Verification Means: • Cross checking vessels position by all appropriate means. Maintaining XTD: • Checking that vessel’s position is maintained within an authorized XTD • including following alterations of course to avoid collision or following a planned alteration of course Navigation Eqpt. Integrity: • Monitoring the integrity of information displayed on navigational equipment. Visual Monitoring Techniques: • Using: • Azimuth bearings. • Heading transits. • Beam transits. • Clearing bearings. Radar Monitoring: • Using: • Parallel Indexing • Radar bearings & ranges. • When radar conspicuous charted features are available. Radar Image Overlay (RIO) • Using RIO. • To counter unforeseen problems, allow flexibility of possible deviations from original plan. In case of any amendments, see section 4.6 . !! AMBIGUITIES & ERRORS If there are 2 or more officers on Bridge, there may be ambiguity over interpretation of information. Resolve any ambiguity, errors, or concern promptly. Also see Doc 5.04 Bridge Team & Resource Management 4.5.2
Toolbox Meetings
Responsibility : Master Hold regular navigation (Toolbox) meetings with the Bridge Team: Before any critical stages of the voyage, or At any other time as deemed necessary. 4.5.3
Monitoring Using ECDIS

Responsibility : OOBW When using ECDIS to monitor passage consider following: Over Reliance on ECDIS: • Avoid over reliance on ECDIS display of position. • Manually verify position using alternate means. Alarms: • Investigate ECDIS alarms immediately. • Where necessary, take action. Reliance on Alarms: • Avoid relying solely on automated monitoring alarms on the ECDIS. Visual Inspection: • Carry out careful visual inspection of the Voyage plan for the period of your watch to confirm that it remains clear of danger. !! Changes may have been applied since last check of the Passage plan. Do not assume review was completed. Viewing More Data: • During above inspection or at any other time, if you consider it necessary to view more data, configure ECDIS display to show all other safety features. • In particular contours & soundings. !! Be aware of the steps to return the ECDIS display to that laid down in the Passage plan for Execution. SCAMIN/ AIO Layer: • To reduce effects of overcrowded display, ensure: • SCAMIN is selected “ON”, & AIO layer is OFF. !! However, at the start of the watch briefly turn on AIO layer to verify they have been plotted and then turn off. Compilation Scale: • Ensure ECDIS is operated at compilation scale when appropriate scale ENCs are available. Safety Domain: • Set the Safety Domain (Vector and Sector) for timely detection of: • Safety contours, • Danger areas, • Fixed or floating aid to navigation, or • Isolated dangers. • For details on setting of safety Domain (Vector and sector), see Doc 5.19.00 Sec 6.3 Managing Information: • Manage the amount of information displayed on the ECDIS. !! To avoid obscuring charted features & information. Voyage Notes: • Look ahead to check for any Voyage Notes. Time Settings: • Verify tome settings are based on Local time. Software Anomalies: • Be aware of the potential for and likely consequences of software anomalies. • For detailed information on ECDIS, see Doc 5.19.00 & Doc 5.20 4.6

Amendments to the Passage Plan • Do not make any changes to passage plan during voyage, without approval of Master. Reasons for Amendments These may include: Change of Destination port, Heavy weather along planned passage. Navigational warning(s) etc. Recommendation by Pilot. Unexpected Anchoring. Failure or malfunction of Equipment or machinery e.g., Navigational equipment. !! Consider the effect of any advances in the planned passage e.g., because of good weather, currents. This can place the vessel in constrained or tidal waters earlier than expected. Amendment & Approval Process Responsibility : Navigation Officer/ OOBW For: Minor amendments - Make relevant changes in the plan and highlight same. Major amendments - Prepare a new voyage plan. Responsibility : Master Review and approve amendments to the plan. Responsibility : Navigation Officer/ OOBW Transfer the plan to monitoring station. Discuss the amendments with other navigating officers. 4.7
Debriefing of the Passage Plan Post Voyage

Responsibility : Master Upon completion of voyage: Conduct debriefing of the passage with all deck officers. Identify any learnings (new hazards, useful information), and proposed improvements to future plans. Record this meeting and any suggestions in form F088 Passage Planning . Include following points as a minimum: Charts & publications suitable for the voyage, Bridge Team synthesis adequate, Any amendments required to the departure port information, Any amendments required to the arrival port information, Actual UKC experienced during passage, anchor, berth in line with the calculated UKC, ECDIS safety and alarm settings were suitable across respective legs of the voyage, Position Verification/Fixing interval stated in passage plan adequate & practical to comply with, Any special conditions experienced (Heavy traffic / Local anomalies /Near Miss etc.) Further scope for improvement to future passage plans. 5.
